posts.post_content:
I don't understand, if you have a enchant land or whatever give off 2 mana you still have to tap magus. So one mana to untap magnus would give you three mana. at the resolve...not infinite. Or can you untap/tap land as much as you please?
  
   
Spell this out for me please
  
   
What I assume is say for instant you have wild growth giving you 2 mana for one tap.....you tap that 2 mana and pay 1 and tap magus , then you can untap that land again to tap for another 2 giving 3 in total, because you can't tap magus again. While good it's not the two card infinate set you would need a creature/spell that untaps magus and a multiple mana producer to make infinite combo, or use this for a multiple color deck to untap specific lands
  
   
Then again I could be blatantly wrong not sure.
  
   
update....yeah I see now. It isn't the infinite mana spewer some of these guys are saying unless you throw in a [freed from the real](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=freed from the real) and a double mana. Then that is the infinite loop

posts.post_content:
This isn't strictly worse than [Candelabra of Tawnos](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Candelabra of Tawnos).   
  
See, there are many other spells that can untap a creature, and if you had the right amount of things, you could make infinite mana.   
  
To stay in Green, let's use [Caged Sun](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Caged Sun) or [Mana Reflection](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mana Reflection) or [Gauntlet of Power](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gauntlet of Power) + [Umbral Mantle](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Umbral Mantle).  
  
If you had 2 forests, you can tap the 2 (![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)), untap them with Magus(![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)), tap the 2 again (![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)), then untap the Magus with the Mantle(![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)). You'll have a net-gain of ![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol) each time. Repeat until you commander [Kamahl, Fist of Krosa](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Kamahl, Fist of Krosa) has stopped pooping himself with his [Overrun](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Overrun) ability or just attack with the infinite/infinite Magus.
posts.html:
This isn't strictly worse than Candelabra of Tawnos.

See, there are many other spells that can untap a creature, and if you had the right amount of things, you could make infinite mana.

To stay in Green, let's use Caged Sun or Mana Reflection or Gauntlet of Power + Umbral Mantle.

If you had 2 forests, you can tap the 2 (), untap them with Magus(), tap the 2 again (), then untap the Magus with the Mantle(). You'll have a net-gain of each time. Repeat until you commander Kamahl, Fist of Krosa has stopped pooping himself with his Overrun ability or just attack with the infinite/infinite Magus.

posts.post_content: As others have said, it's good with multi-mana lands like the Ravnica bouncelands, Gaea's Cradle, or something with Wild Growth on it, and it's great with [Mana Flare](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mana Flare)-type effects. But even without any of that, it's also color-filtering. If you have, say, two Forests and two Plains, you could use this to get ![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol)![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol)![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol)![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol) or ![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol) instead of just ![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol)![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol).
posts.html:
As others have said, it's good with multi-mana lands like the Ravnica bouncelands, Gaea's Cradle, or something with Wild Growth on it, and it's great with Mana Flare-type effects. But even without any of that, it's also color-filtering. If you have, say, two Forests and two Plains, you could use this to get or instead of just .
